action->Protean Anatomy.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-family-ability-glossary.Item.IOk0MRs3f9FrarKL]

A voidworm's vital organs shift and change shape and position constantly. Immediately after the voidworm takes acid, electricity, or sonic damage, they gains the listed amount of resistance to that damage type. This lasts for 1 hour or until the next time the voidworm takes damage of one of the other types (in which case its resistance changes to match that type), whichever comes first.

The voidworm is immune to polymorph effects unless it is a willing target. If @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.9PR9y0bi4JPKnHPR]{Deafened}, the voidworm automatically recovers at the end of its next turn as new sensory organs grow to replace the compromised ones.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.c6SiBB3mzV8lZUQr]{Effect: Protean Anatomy}

action->Change Shape.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.eQM5hQ1W3d1uen97]

The voidworm takes on the appearance of a Tiny animal. This doesn't change their Speed or their attack and damage bonuses with their Strikes but might change the damage type their Strikes deal.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

action->Confounding Lash.name: Confounding Lash
action->Confounding Lash.description: A creature hit by the voidworm's tail Strike is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 1 round (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} on a critical hit). A successful @Check[will|dc:16] save negates this effect and grants temporary immunity to confounding lash for 1 minute.

Vordine.name: Vordine
Vordine.publicNotes:
The vast city of Dis trains endless legions of vordines to guard the upper layers of Hell and march across the planes at the archdevils' orders. Although quick to bend their knees to higher-ranking devils and even mortals favored by Asmodeus, vordines are relentlessly cruel to orts and other devils they can call their subordinates.

Although higher ranks in the infernal military are held by more powerful devils, like the nessari who serve as generals, a labyrinthine structure gives each vordine a rank and certain responsibilities. Some vordines are responsible for the battlefield command of squads, while others relay orders from above or are set to handling specific administrative tasks for their unit. The greatest gift one can offer a vordine is an increased rank to lord over other vordines.

Masters of corruption and architects of conquest, devils seek both to tempt mortal life to join in their pursuit of all things profane and to spread tyranny throughout all worlds. The temptations they offer mortals range from great powers granted by the signing of an infernal contract to twisted favors following a whispered pledge to a diabolic patron, or any number of even subtler exchanges. Those who succumb to these temptations find themselves consigned to an afterlife of endless torment in the pits of Hell, wherein the only hope of escape lies in the chance of being promoted to become a devil in the infernal ranks.

Every devil has a specific role to play in the upkeep of the remorseless bureaucratic machine that is Hell, from soldiers and scholars to inquisitors, lawyers, judges, and executioners. Lowly orts perform subservient labor to more powerful and specialized devils, such as infantry and contract devils, while the greatest nessaris command entire infernal armies.

Asmodeus stands at the apex of the structure he created, but the layers below him are marked by a constant jockeying for position. Most diabolic plans ultimately serve to improve the schemer's place in the hierarchy.
Vordine.saveDetails: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->Burning Hoofprints.name: Burning Hoofprints
action->Burning Hoofprints.description: The vordine Strides, trailing hoofprints in each square they exit. The hoofprints burn for 1 minute. A creature on the ground that enters a square with burning hoofprints or begins its turn in one takes @Damage[1d4[fire]] damage.

action->Trident of Dis.name: Trident of Dis
action->Trident of Dis.description: The vordine makes a trident Strike, increasing their reach to 10 feet for that Strike. If there is an unholy ally between the vordine and their target, that creature's energy causes the Strike to deal an additional 1d6 spirit damage.

Vrolikai.name: Vrolikai
Vrolikai.publicNotes:
Powerful vrolikais command the untamed armies of demonkind, uniting them behind their one unifying desire for death and destruction. Unlike other demons, the dreaded vrolikai doesn't form directly from a single soul—they instead manifest when a demon devours so many damned souls that their own individual desires are lost in the sinful cacophony. A vrolikai who survives this process gains great power and can claim a region of the Outer Rifts as their own domain.

Vrolikais' enthusiastic embrace of the multitude of sins makes them uniquely suited to lead and unite demons, such that even demon lords often must rely on vrolikais to command their forces. The chaotic and conflicting motivations of demonkind leave little room to find common ground, but the vrolikai can expound upon the beauty of every kind of sin while marching demon armies to battle.

When a sinful mortal soul is judged and sent on to the Outer Rifts, it can become a deadly fiend—a demon. Demons are living incarnations of sin—be they classic sins like wrath or gluttony, or more "specialized" depravities like an obsession with torture or the act of treason or treachery. Once formed, a demon's driving goals are twofold—the amassing of personal power, and the corruption of mortal souls to cause them to become tainted by sin. In this way demons ensure a never-ending supply of new demons to bolster their ever-growing ranks in the Outer Rifts.

Demons are selfish and self-absorbed creatures, and most firmly believe that mortals only play at being more virtuous than fiends. They enjoy tempting mortals into damnation to both indulge their egos and swell their armies. Like many other fiends, one of the great rewards of this manipulation is fulfilling their hunger for souls. In their eyes, the primary use for these souls is to spawn new demons, who can serve as soldiers, slaves, pawns, or even currency for their more powerful masters.

action->Death-Stealing Gaze.name: Death-Stealing Gaze
action->Death-Stealing Gaze.description:
30 feet. When a non-demon ends its turn in the aura, it must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:38] save. If it fails, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}.

A creature that dies while it has drain from a vrolikai's gaze rises as a ghoul the next midnight. The GM determines what kind of ghoul.

action->Black Flame Knives.name: Black Flame Knives
action->Black Flame Knives.description: The vrolikai manifests a dagger-shaped blade of what looks like crystallized black flame in each of their four hands. These weapons function as +2 greater striking daggers that deal an additional 2d6 void damage. They fade away into nothingness 1 minute after a vrolikai no longer carries them.

action->Consume Death.name: Consume Death
action->Consume Death.description:
The vrolikai focuses their deathstealing gaze upon a single target they can see within 30 feet. The target must immediately attempt a Fortitude save against death-stealing gaze.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is affected by death-stealing gaze and becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}. If the creature was already drained 1 by the death-stealing gaze before attempting the save, a failed save increases the value of the drained condition by 1, to a maximum of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 4}. The vrolikai gains 10 temporary Hit Points, and the drained creature is temporarily immune until the start of the vrolikai's next turn.

Critical Failure As failure, but the creature increases the amount of drain by 2.

action->Focused Flames.name: Focused Flames
action->Focused Flames.description:
The vrolikai attacks a single target with all of their black flame knives. The demon makes a black flame knife Strike with the following additional effects. This counts toward the vrolikai's multiple attack penalty as a number of attacks equal to the number of back flame knives the vrolikai used.

Critical Success The target takes an additional 2d6 void damage for each knife beyond the first (typically @Damage[6d6[void]]{6d6 extra damage}) and takes @Damage[4d6[persistent,void]] damage.

Success The target takes an additional 2d6 void damage for each knife beyond the first.

Failure The vrolikai deals the damage their black flame knife Strike normally deals on a hit.

action->Mindwarping.name: Mindwarping
action->Mindwarping.description:
The sting of a vrolikai is mind-warping. A creature struck must attempt a @Check[will|dc:44] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} for 1 minute.

Failure The creature becomes stupefied 1. If it's already stupefied, its stupefied value increases by 1 instead (to a maximum of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 4}).

Critical Failure As failure, plus the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 minute.

War Horse.name: Caballo de guerra
War Horse.publicNotes: Los caballos se usan como monturas y animales de carga en muchas sociedades. Son criaturas leales y normalmente afables y son inestimables para cualquiera que tenga que viajar grandes distancias. Las razas más pequeñas, como los gnomos y los medianos, a menudo utilizan ponis como monturas, mientras que los caballos son los preferidos por los humanos y otros humanoides de tamaño Mediano. La mayoría de caballos con que se encuentra el humanoide promedio están domesticados, aunque también hay grandes manadas salvajes de estos magníficos animales.

action->Gallop.name: Galope
action->Gallop.description: El caballo de guerra da dos Zancadas. Tiene un bonificador de +10 pies (3 m) por circunstancia a su velocidad durante estas Zancadas.

War Pony.name: Poni de guerra
War Pony.publicNotes: Los caballos se usan como monturas y animales de carga en muchas sociedades. Son criaturas leales y normalmente afables y son inestimables para cualquiera que tenga que viajar grandes distancias. Las razas más pequeñas, como los gnomos y los medianos, a menudo utilizan ponis como monturas, mientras que los caballos son los preferidos por los humanos y otros humanoides de tamaño Mediano. La mayoría de caballos con que se encuentra el humanoide promedio están domesticados, aunque también hay grandes manadas salvajes de estos magníficos animales.

action->Gallop.name: Galope
action->Gallop.description: El poni de monta da dos Zancadas. Tiene un bonificador de +10 pies (3 m) por circunstancia a su velocidad durante estas Zancadas.

Warg.name: Warg
Warg.publicNotes:
Wargs hunt in packs like wolves, but their penchant for taunting victims makes them easy to distinguish from their cousins. Orcs and hobgoblins frequently recruit wargs. Most wargs are amenable to this arrangement, but if food should run out, wargs are more than willing to integrate goblinoid flesh into their diet.

The warg is an intelligent and malevolent wolf that dwells among goblins, hobgoblins, orcs, and violent humanoids.

action->Avenging Bite.name: Avenging Bite
action->Avenging Bite.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of the warg's jaws attacks one of the warg's allies.

Effect The warg makes a jaws Strike against the triggering creature.

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The warg's Strikes deals an extra 1d4 damage to any creature within reach of at least two of the warg's allies.

Small, @Damage[(1d6+2)[bludgeoning]], Rupture 9

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.SwallowWhole]

Warsworn.name: Warsworn
Warsworn.publicNotes: A warsworn is an animate mass of corpses composed of dozens, sometimes even hundreds, of victims of battle. They are formed by deities of undeath or war or, rarely, spontaneously manifest from the devastation of an especially horrendous battle.
Warsworn.saveDetails: +1 status to all saves vs. vitality

action->Absorb.name: Absorb
action->Absorb.description:
Trigger The warsworn moves into a dying creature's space;

Effect The warsworn absorbs the dying creature into itself, instantly killing the creature and healing the warsworn for a number of Hit Points equal to the creature's level. As long as the warsworn still exists, absorbed creatures can't be resurrected except by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{Wish} or a similarly powerful effect.

action->Animated Weapons.name: Animated Weapons
action->Animated Weapons.description:
100 feet.

The warsworn automatically controls unattended weapons in the aura, which levitate around the warsworn. The warsworn can telekinetically wield these weapons to make melee Strikes with a reach of 100 feet. These strikes deal four of the weapon's damage dice +9 and use the weapon's damage type.

action->Energy Drain.name: Energy Drain
action->Energy Drain.description: When a warsworn hits with a corpse wave Strike or damages a creature with Trample, the target must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:35] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 1}. On a critical success, the target becomes temporarily immune to the warsworn's energy drain for 24 hours.

action->Plummet.name: Plummet
action->Plummet.description: A creature hit by a warsworn's scrap ball Strike must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:37] save. On a failure, the target falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}; if the target was airborne, it falls up to 120 feet, taking damage from the fall and landing prone if the descent brings it to the ground. On a critical failure, the target is also held under a pile of scrap ([[/act escape dc=37]]).

action->Trample.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.UNah0bxXxkcZjxO3]

Huge or smaller, corpse wave, @Check[reflex|dc:37|basic]

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Trample]

Wasp Swarm.name: Plaga de avispas
Wasp Swarm.publicNotes:
Los nidos de avispa están hechos de fibras de madera masticada recolectadas de la zona circundante, que las avispas convierten en un material parecido al papel. Un solo nido de avispas puede albergar miles de individuos que emergen como una plaga masiva. La mayoría de plagas solo atacan para proteger su nido o si se las agita de alguna otra forma, aunque los druidas y otros encantadores primigenios pueden doblegar a su voluntad a estas sabandijas venenosas, con efectos letales.

Aunque una avispa común no supone peligro alguno para un aventurero curtido, más allá de una molesta picadura, una plaga grande y agresiva de tan territoriales insectos (por no hablar de sus variantes de gran tamaño) puede abatir a un grupo entero de héroes. Las avispas representadas aquí son de la variedad común, también conocida como chaquetas amarillas, pero existen muchos otros tipos de avispas peligrosas, como por ejemplo una variante de Garund cuyas plagas pueden diezmar poblados enteros debido a su gran número.

action->Swarming Stings.name: Aguijones de la plaga
action->Swarming Stings.description: Cada enemigo en el espacio de la plaga sufre 2d8 daño perforante (salvación básica de Reflejos CD 21). Una criatura que falla su salvación queda además expuesta al veneno de avispa.

action->Wasp Venom.name: Veneno de avispa
action->Wasp Venom.description:
Tirada de Salvación @Check[fortitude|dc:21]

Duración máxima 6 asaltos

Etapa 1 @Damage[1d6[poison]]{1d6 veneno} (1 asalto)

Etapa 2 @Damage[2d6[poison]]{2d6 veneno} y @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Torpe 2} (2 asaltos)

Water Scamp.name: Water Scamp
Water Scamp.publicNotes:
Water scamps are marked apart from other scamps by sleek fur that traps a layer of water next to their skin. Although they can fly like their kin and conjure enough water to never dry out, water scamps leave the water only when they must. Although air-breathing scholars consider these scamps quiet and rather skittish, underwater civilizations find their exuberance and playfulness can be overwhelming.

Elemental scamps are bat-like critters marked by elemental powers. Scamps are dispatched from the Elemental Planes by more powerful residents or called to the Universe by neophyte summoners. All scamps have a hint of magical power due to a lingering connection to their home plane, which they largely use to pull simple pranks.

Scamps rapidly form a pecking order of cleverness. Humanoids often confuse scamps when meeting such creatures for the first time. These confused scamps usually resort to an escalating series of pranks and mischief, seeing what they can get away with to establish their place in the hierarchy.

action->Fast Healing 2 (While Underwater.name:
<Compendium> tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.fJSNOw4zHGbIm4bZ]
Fast Healing 2 (While Underwater)

action->Acid Breath.name: Acid Breath
action->Acid Breath.description:
The water scamp breathes acid in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[2d6[acid]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:17|basic|options:area-effect] save).

The water scamp can't use Acid Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Acid Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Drench.name: Drench
action->Drench.description: The water scamp shakes out a seemingly endless supply of water from its fur to put out all fires in a @Template[emanation|distance:5]. The scamp extinguishes all non-magical fires automatically and attempts to counteract magical fires ([[/r 1d20+7 #Counteract]]{+7} counteract modifier).

Werebear.name: Werebear
Werebear.publicNotes:
Unwavering conviction fills a werebear during their transformations. This can drive them zealously into noble causes, but it can also make them ruthless, violent, and single-minded. Alliances can fall from a werebear's mind as their bestial temper overcomes them and their goal overwhelms all. As a result, werebears are loners, rarely even living together as families longer than necessary. As long as there is nothing around to threaten it or the natural area it protects (typically a forest), a werebear in its animal form is generally content to forage and sleep away the night.

Werecreatures are humanoids doomed to transform into animals and animalhumanoid hybrids under the light of the full moon. These shapechanging creatures are the result of an ancient primal curse that they can, in turn, transmit through their own bites. Their ability to lurk unseen in the wilds as well as among people, combined with the contagiousness of their condition, makes werecreatures a perennial cause of panicked suspicion.

The werecreature changes into its humanoid, hybrid, or animal shape. Each shape has a specific, persistent appearance. A true werecreature's natural form is its hybrid shape.

In humanoid shape, the werecreature uses its original humanoid size, loses its jaws and claws Strikes, and gains a melee fist Strike that deals bludgeoning damage equal to the slashing damage dealt by its claw.

In animal shape, its Speed and size change to that of the animal, it gains any special Strike effects of the animal that it didn't already have (such as Grab), and it loses its weapon Strikes.

action->Hunt Prey.name: Hunt Prey
action->Hunt Prey.description: The werebear designates a single creature they can see and hear, or one they're Tracking, as their prey. The werebear gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Perception checks when they @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.BlAOM2X92SI6HMtJ]{Seek} their prey and to Survival checks when they @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EA5vuSgJfiHH7plD]{Track} their prey. The first time the werebear hits the designated prey in a round, they deal an additional 1d8 precision damage. These effects last until the werebear uses Hunt Prey again.

action->Mauler.name: Mauler
action->Mauler.description: The werebear gains a +2 circumstance bonus to damage rolls against creatures it has @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}.

Wererat.name: Wererat
Wererat.publicNotes:
Wererats tend to be selfishly opportunistic, avaricious, and paranoid as a result of their curse. Because wererats typically dwell in metropolitan areas where they can hide in plain sight, practically any city goer could be a wererat in disguise—from the quiet shopkeep to the city's criminal mastermind. The bustle of crowds and countless rat holes make ghettos and shantytowns favored homes for wererats, especially since in these poorer districts the wererat can kill out of greed or fear with little chance of the authorities noticing. In some cities, wererats operate entire thieves' guilds or organized crime rings, and membership requires willfully submitting to the wererat's cursed bite. Wererats look very similar to ratfolk when in hybrid form, apart from potential differences in size, but ratfolk have no love for wererats.

Werecreatures are humanoids doomed to transform into animals and animalhumanoid hybrids under the light of the full moon. These shapechanging creatures are the result of an ancient primal curse that they can, in turn, transmit through their own bites. Their ability to lurk unseen in the wilds as well as among people, combined with the contagiousness of their condition, makes werecreatures a perennial cause of panicked suspicion.

Weretiger.name: Weretiger
Weretiger.publicNotes:
These ferocious werecreatures stalk prey with the cunning and skill of a true apex predator. Weretigers typically view all life as a potential meal. Powerful nocturnal hunters with excellent senses that help them ambush prey, weretigers are adaptable to an extreme range of environments. However, weretigers living in densely populated cities (potentially as courtesans, assassins, or guild leaders) often struggle to suppress their killer instincts, becoming overwhelmed by the urge to hunt.

Werecreatures are humanoids doomed to transform into animals and animalhumanoid hybrids under the light of the full moon. These shapechanging creatures are the result of an ancient primal curse that they can, in turn, transmit through their own bites. Their ability to lurk unseen in the wilds as well as among people, combined with the contagiousness of their condition, makes werecreatures a perennial cause of panicked suspicion.

Werewolf.name: Hombre lobo
Werewolf.publicNotes:
La maldición del hombre lobo infunde en sus portadores el ansia de sangre y los instintos depredadores de un lobo. Los hombres lobo suelen residir en los márgenes de la sociedad o en asentamientos pequeños en los que, en su forma humanoide, trabajan como obreros, cazadores, granjeros o tramperos. Por la noche, sin embargo, estos mismos aldeanos se transforman en violentos homicidas y sádicos acechadores que se alimentan de sus vecinos. Los hombres lobo son los licántropos por antonomasia y en lo primero en que piensa la gente cuando le hablas de licantropía.

Aunque la mayoría de hombres lobo esconden su maldición a base de adoptar un estilo de vida solitario, algunos conservan la mentalidad de manada de los lobos. Un pequeño grupo de estos hombres lobo suele formar una manada familiar, en la que el miembro de mayor edad o más poderoso sirve como nuevo líder; a medida que la influencia de esa manada crece, acepta nuevos miembros tras seleccionarlos cuidadosamente.

Los licántropos son humanoides condenados a transformarse en animales y en híbridos de humanoide y animal bajo la luz de la luna llena. Estas criaturas cambiaformas son el resultado de una ancestral maldición primigenia que pueden, a su vez, transmitir a través de sus propios mordiscos. Su capacidad de acechar sin llamar la atención tanto en la Naturaleza como en asentamientos humanoides, combinado con el carácter contagioso de su aflicción, hace de los licántropos una causa perenne de sospecha y pánico. Aunque el nombre ‘licántropo’ deriva de ‘hombre lobo’, ha pasado a usarse para toda esta clase de cambiaformas animales.

action->Wolf Empathy.name: (Licántropo) Empatía animal
action->Wolf Empathy.description:
El hombre lobo puede comunicarse con criaturas caninas.

El licántropo puede hacer preguntas, recibir respuestas y utilizar la habilidad Diplomacia con animales de su especie.

action->Change Shape.name: Cambiar de forma
action->Change Shape.description:
• Humano
    • Cuerpo a cuerpo puño +11 Daño 1d4+8
  • Animal
    • Velocidad 40 pies (12 m)
    • Cuepo a cuerpo Mandíbulas con @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.BCLvAx4Pz4MLa2pu]{Derribar}

El licántropo cambia a su forma humanoide, híbrida o animal. Cada forma tiene una apariencia específica y persistente. La forma natural de un licántropo verdadero es su forma híbrida.

En forma humanoide, el licántropo usa su tamaño de humanoide original, pierde sus Golpes de fauces y garra y obtiene un Golpe de puño cuerpo a cuerpo que inflige tanto daño contundente como el que inflige su garra.

En forma animal, su velocidad y tamaño cambian a los del animal, obtiene cualquier efecto especial del animal a los Golpes que no tuviera ya (como agarrón) y pierde sus Golpes con armas.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

action->Curse of the Werewolf.name: (Licántropo) Maldición de la licantropía
action->Curse of the Werewolf.description:
Esta maldición sólo afecta a humanoides.

Tirada de salvación Salvación La CD de @Check[fortitude|dc:] es la CD estándar para el nuevo nivel del licántropo.

Cada luna llena, la criatura maldita debe tener éxito en otra salvación de Fortaleza o se convierte en el mismo tipo de licántropo hasta el amanecer.

La criatura está bajo el control del DJ y causa estragos durante la mitad de la noche antes de quedar inconsciente hasta el amanecer.

action->Pack Attack.name: Ataque en manada
action->Pack Attack.description: El hombre lobo inflige 1d6 daño adicional a cualquier criatura que está dentro de alcance de por lo menos dos de sus aliados.

Wight.name: Wight
Wight.hpDetails: alimentado por el rencor, curación del vacío
Wight.publicNotes:
Los wights son muertos vivientes inteligentes generados mediante inevitables ciclos de rencor. Este rencor podría proceder de su propia voluntad maligna en vida o haber sido instilado por rituales nigrománticos, que típicamente implican la profanación de los lugares de enterramiento. Suelen acechar en los camposantos, las catacumbas u otros lugares destinados a los muertos. Su hambre se dirige hacia los vivos, cuyos corazones batientes y su rubicundo calor les inspiran un odio visceral.

Existen tantos tipos como tipos de gente a partir de la que podrían haberse creado. Enormes brutos, escurridizos bribones y astutos pensadores acaban formando wights diferentes con sus propias especialidades. El entorno juega también un papel a la hora de determinar las aptitudes especiales y las defensas de uno de ellos. Los wights de la escarcha, por ejemplo, se pueden encontrar en las partes del mundo donde morir de frío es habitual y el resentimiento de haber sido abandonado en el yermo es una fuente común de rencor. Duraderos y mantenidos por la energía del vacío, pueden existir en los entornos rigurosos sin descomponerse en la forma en que lo hacen algunos muertos vivientes menores.

Un solo wight puede causar grandes estragos si se ve obligado a alzarse de su tumba. Como quiera que las criaturas muertas a manos de uno de ellos también se pueden convertir en wights, solo hace falta uno y un puñado de desafortunados visitantes a un cementerio para crear una verdadera horda de estos muertos vivientes. Así pues, los sacerdotes astutos y los aventureros saben que la mejor solución para un problema de wights es exterminarlos de forma rápida y total. Sin embargo, hay que tener cuidado en destruir a los engendros antes de tratar de destruir a su progenitor, puesto que un engendro sin amo obtiene la aptitud de crear engendros propios.

action->Grave Weapon.name: Arma sepulcral
action->Grave Weapon.description: El wight está vinculado a una daga con la que fue enterrado. Otros wights pueden estar vinculados a diferentes armas.

action->Final Spite.name: Rencor final
action->Final Spite.description:
Desencadenante El wight queda reducido a 0 Puntos de Golpe

Efecto El wight da un Golpe antes de ser destruido. Este Golpe puede infligir rencor corruptor, pero no se aplica alimentado por el rencor.

action->Fueled by Spite.name: Alimentado por el rencor
action->Fueled by Spite.description: Cada vez que una criatura pierde Puntos de Golpe debido a una maldición de rencor corruptor infligida por el wight, este obtiene 3 Puntos de Golpe temporales.

action->Corrupting Spite.name: Rencor corruptor
action->Corrupting Spite.description:
Los ataques sin armas y con las armas vinculadas de un wight infligen una maldición que hace que la criatura se vuelva débil y rencorosa. Si un wight inflige rencor corruptor a una criatura ya afligida por ello, la víctima hace una nueva salvación, ignorando el resultado si es mejor que un fallo.

Un humanoide vivo que muere bajo la maldición se alza como un engendro al cabo de [[/gmr 1d4 #Engendro de Wight]]{1d4 asaltos}, controlado por el wight que le mató. El engendro no puede infligir rencor corruptor y queda @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Torpe 2}. Si su creador muere o al cabo de aproximadamente un mes de existencia, se vuelve autónomo y se convierte en un wight normal

Tirada de Salvación @Check[fortitude|dc:17];

Etapa 1 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drenado 1} (1 asalto)

Etapa 2 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drenado 2} y no trata a ninguna criatura como a un aliado (1 asalto)

Etapa 3 como la etapa 2, excepto @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drenado 3} (1 asalto)

Etapa 4 como la etapa 2, excepto @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drenado 4} (1 asalto).

Will-o'-Wisp.name: Fuego fatuo
Will-o'-Wisp.publicNotes:
Los fuegos fatuos son bolas malignas de luces de colores, que acechan en marismas y bosques solitarios, donde atraen al peligro a viajeros incautos. Pueden variar el color y la iluminación que emiten y les encanta imitar el movimiento de las lámparas de aceite o el fulgor de las fogatas lejanas, para apartar de los senderos seguros a los viajeros perdidos o desorientados. Pueden apagar por completo su iluminación para hacerse @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.zJxUflt9np0q4yML]{Invisibles}, y les gusta hacerlo una vez sus víctimas están completamente perdidas y se han dado cuenta de que la luz que se movía en la distancia no los llevaba a ningún lugar seguro. Sin embargo, incluso invisibles, raramente se alejan demasiado de su objetivo, puesto que se alimentan del pánico y el terror de este.

Bajo su brillo, un fuego fatuo es una bola esponjosa de aproximadamente un pie (30 cm) de diámetro, que pesa menos de 5 libras (2,25 kg). Aunque la mayor parte son simplemente orbes translúcidos carentes de rasgos, que obtienen definición tan solo por la iluminación cambiante que emiten, unos pocos tienen manchas oscuras que les hacen parecer calaveras cuando se les ve de cerca. Los fuegos fatuos no necesitan alimentación mundana y, de hecho, carecen de la aptitud de consumir ningún tipo de materia; obtienen todo el sustento que necesitan del terror de las criaturas cercanas. Por este motivo, les gusta trabajar junto a muertos vivientes que generan terror en sus víctimas. Tienen una vida muy larga, hasta el punto de parecer efectivamente inmortales, y muy buena memoria. Un fuego fatuo acobardado o derrotado puede ser una buena fuente de información y de saber, aunque conseguir semejante cooperación de un monstruo tan siniestro no es tarea fácil.

Suelen habitar en pantanos y bosques desolados y generalmente se activan al atardecer y por la noche. Son reticentes a conducir a sus víctimas a zonas inmediatamente fatales como despeñaderos, y prefieren riesgos en los que sus víctimas sufren durante bastante tiempo, como por ejemplo bolsas de aire viciado o venenoso, tramos de arenas movedizas y guaridas de monstruos más grandes. Según ellos, los diferentes tipos de miedo tienen sutiles diferencias de sabor. El desasosiego en la boca del estómago que corroe a quienes se dan cuenta poco a poco de que se han perdido, produce un sabor muy diferente al terror repentino de la muerte inminente frente a un monstruo enorme. Debido a ello, tratan de variar las formas mediante las que inducen el terror en sus presas, para asegurarse de que no se cansan de ciertos sabores del miedo.

action->Glow.name: Resplandor
action->Glow.description:
20 pies (6 m)

Un fuego fatuo es de por sí invisible, pero brilla con luces de colores emitiendo luz brillante en el aura, lo que le hace visible.

action->Magic Immunity.name: Inmunidad a la magia
action->Magic Immunity.description: El fuego fatuo es inmune a todos los conjuros salvo @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.gKKqvLohtrSJj3BM]{Descarga de fuerza}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Oj1PJBMQD9vuwCv7]{Dilema}, y @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0qaqksrGGDj74HXE]{Luz reveladora}.

action->Feed on Fear.name: Alimentarse del miedo
action->Feed on Fear.description:
Frecuencia una vez por asalto

Requisitos Un enemigo a 15 pies (4,5 m) está sufriendo un efecto de miedo o moribundo

Efecto El fuego fatuo se alimenta del terror de la criatura. Recupera @Damage[2d4[healing]]{2d4 Puntos de Golpe} y, si se ha Apagado, su resplandor se reinicia.

action->Go Dark.name: Apagarse
action->Go Dark.description: El fuego fatuo apaga su resplandor, haciéndose @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.zJxUflt9np0q4yML]{Invisible}. Puede acabar este efecto con otro uso de esta acción. Si utiliza su ataque de chispazo mientras está invisible, el arco eléctrico permite a cualquier observador determinar dónde se encuentra, haciendo que solo esté @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Escondido} ante todos los observadores hasta que se mueve.

Winged Chupacabra.name: Winged Chupacabra
Winged Chupacabra.publicNotes:
Some chupacabras are mutants with large reptilian wings and have been known to carry off goats or even children.

These notorious predators have an undeniable thirst for blood. Chupacabras prefer to prey on the weak and slow, often hiding in wait and watching potential prey for long periods before attacking. Spry and stealthy, they most often make their homes in areas of high grass and protective rock, their slightly reflective scales allowing them to blend in well with such surroundings.

Chupacabras prefer to eat lone travelers and farm animals (particularly goats) and leave little evidence of their presence apart from the grisly, blood-drained husks of their meals. Their tendency to stay out of sight combined with their naturally nocturnal activity often leads superstitious locals to conclude the worst, imagining that a particularly reckless vampire lives in the area.

A typical chupacabra measures nearly 4 feet from its muzzle to the tip of its spiny tail, and it stands just under 3-1/2 feet tall. With their slight build and lightweight bones, most weigh close to 50 pounds. They mate rarely and only during the hottest months, with the females each producing a single egg that hatches into a tiny, dehydrated creature. The mother usually leaves helpless prey in her cave so the hatchling can immediately feed.

Although chupacabras are typically solitary creatures, they have been known to form small gangs in bountiful areas. Members of these groups work well together, growing bold enough to attack larger animals, small herds, and otherwise more dangerous prey. Stories of chupacabras attacking travelers or laying siege to farmhouses typically stem from the hunting practices of such gangs. Regions where chupacabra activity like this is more common often have complex and colorful myths and tall tales about chupacabra capabilities or motive—and a few of the claims, such as that some chupacabras can fly, are all too true.

action->Pounce.name: Pounce
action->Pounce.description: The chupacabra Strides and makes a Strike at the end of that movement. If the chupacabra began this action @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden}, it remains hidden until after this ability's Strike.

action->Suck Blood.name: Suck Blood
action->Suck Blood.description:
Requirements The chupacabra has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}

Effect The chupacabra sucks blood from the grabbed creature. The chupacabra gains the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} condition for 1 minute and can use the extra action only for Strike and Stride actions.

A chupacabra can't Suck Blood again while it is quickened in this way.

A creature that has its blood drained by a chupacabra is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} until it receives healing (of any kind or amount).

Witchwarg.name: Witchwarg
Witchwarg.publicNotes:
Witchwargs are related to wargs, but are larger, smarter, and far more dangerous. They are capable of exhaling plumes of freezing breath. When they deign to serve others, they usually reserve this privilege for more dangerous creatures, such as the winter witches of Irrisen.

The warg is an intelligent and malevolent wolf that dwells among goblins, hobgoblins, orcs, and violent humanoids.

action->Avenging Bite.name: Avenging Bite
action->Avenging Bite.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of the witchwarg's jaws attacks one of the witchwarg's allies.

Effect The witchwarg makes a jaws Strike against the triggering creature.

action->Buck.description:
tag will get replaced with text from compendium entry @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.nZMQh4AaBr291TUf]

@Check[reflex|dc:21]

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Buck]

action->Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
action->Pack Attack.description: The witchwarg's Strikes deal 1d6 extra damage to creatures within the reach of at least two of the witchwarg's allies.

action->Winter Breath.name: Winter Breath
action->Winter Breath.description:
The witchwarg breathes a cloud of frost in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[5d8[cold]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:23|basic] save).

The witchwarg can't use Winter Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Winter Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

Wolf.name: Lobo
Wolf.publicNotes:
Los lobos viven y cazan en manadas que, al contrario de lo que la gente cree, no están lideradas por el más fuerte del grupo, sino que suelen consistir en una pareja, sus cachorros y retoños jóvenes de anteriores épocas de cría. Los retoños generalmente abandonan la manada de sus padres cuando terminan de crecer, tras lo cual buscan pareja propia para formar una manada en otro lugar. Los lobos no suelen ver a los humanoides como presa, pero circunstancias extraordinarias pueden llevar a estos animales a atacar a la gente, especialmente en los meses de invierno y otras situaciones en que sus presas típicas (principalmente ciervos y alces) escasean. Algunos seres, como los vampiros poderosos, pueden llamar a lobos para que les ayuden en combate.

Los lobos vagan por bosques, colinas y otras regiones salvajes, donde cazan en manada para acosar y rodear a sus presas antes de matarlas. Como la mayoría de depredadores, los lobos prefieren atacar a las presas más débiles o más vulnerables que pueden encontrar.

action->Pack Attack.name: Ataque en manada
action->Pack Attack.description: El lobo inflige 1d4 daño adicional a cualquier criatura que está dentro de alcance de por lo menos dos de sus aliados.

Woolly Rhinoceros.name: Rinoceronte lanudo
Woolly Rhinoceros.publicNotes:
Incluso más voluminosos que sus parientes lampiños, estos rinocerontes tienen un pelaje desgreñado largo y grueso y un enorme cuerno en forma de media luna. Los rinocerontes lanudos habitan áreas de tundra árida y estepas frías, y pasan gran parte del día pastando para alimentarse.

Este robusto animal es fácilmente reconocible por el distintivo cuerno que le brota del hocico. Los rinocerontes son herbívoros y, a pesar de su enorme tamaño, pueden correr a una velocidad considerable. Si bien tienen buen oído y un agudo sentido del olfato, su vista es relativamente mala.
Woolly Rhinoceros.saveDetails: +2 por estatus a todas las salvaciones contra el frío

action->+2 Status to All Saves vs. Cold.name: +2 por estatus a todas las salvaciones contra el frío

action->Cold Adaptation.name: Adaptación al frío
action->Cold Adaptation.description: El rinoceronte lanudo trata los efectos ambientales de frío como si fueran un grado menos severos.

action->Rhinoceros Charge.name: Carga de rinoceronte
action->Rhinoceros Charge.description: El rinoceronte da dos Zancadas y después un Golpe con el cuerno. Si se mueve por lo menos 20 pies (6 m), el daño del Golpe se incrementa a @Damage[(3d12+6)[piercing]]{3d12+6}. Una criatura Mediana o más pequeña impactada por este ataque debe tener éxito en una salvación de @Check[reflex|dc:24] o ser automáticamente @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Empujada} hacia atrás 5 pies (1,5 m) y quedar @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Tumbada} por la fuerza del golpe.

Wraith.name: Wraith
Wraith.publicNotes:
Los wraiths son muertos vivientes malignos que drenan vitalidad y evitan la luz. Sus sombrías formas están cubiertas por ropajes insustanciales que lucen como un emblema de autoridad y cuentan con unos ojos que miran detenidamente y que reflejan su opinión sobre los vivos. Un wraith puede ser creado mediante magia vil o mediante una exposición directa al Vacío, pero más a menudo es el resultado de una muerte a escala trágica. Cuando una tragedia es demasiado grande incluso para que la realidad sea testigo de ella, una manifestación temporal del vacío puede dejar atrás incontables wraiths en una horda de oscuridad. Su existencia se basa en el vacuidad y en la necesidad, así como en el deseo de llevar a otros a la misma vacuidad de la que el Vacío es el mejor ejemplo.

Los wraiths pueden acechar en cualquier lugar en el que puedan interactuar de forma segura con los vivos, buscando a quienes son dignos de convertirse en nuevos wraiths y eliminando al resto, aunque su vulnerabilidad a la luz solar les confina a los lugares sombríos del mundo, donde pueden fundirse por completo con sus oscuros alrededores antes de caer en silencio sobre sus presas. La opinión de los wraiths acerca de quién es digno o no es variable, pero típicamente eligen a quienes están ya más cerca del Vacío, ya sea a partir de una conexión metafísica o de estar expuestos a incontables muertes. Un nuevo wraith creado de esta forma conserva dichos aspectos, mientras que el resto de su personalidad es deformado o arrancado por su exposición al Vacío.

Los wraiths se reúnen con otros de su especie en lugares donde la muerte y el caos son comunes: paisajes asolados por la guerra, bajos fondos metropolitanos dirigidos por señores del crimen o escenarios de rituales infernales. En esos lugares, los vivos harán bien en disponer de luz abundante. Los wraiths son lo suficientemente inteligentes como para sacar partido de su incorporalidad en combate, por lo que se ciñen a cavernas tortuosas o estructuras con pasillos, evitando las zonas abiertas.

action->Lifesense 60 feet.name: Sentido de la vida 60 pies (18 m)

action->Sunlight Powerlessness.name: Impotencia ante la luz del sol
action->Sunlight Powerlessness.description: Cuando está bajo la luz solar, un wraith está @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Cegado} y @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Lentificado 2}.

action->Grip of Fear.name: Presa del pánico
action->Grip of Fear.description: El wraith extiende su mano al pecho de una criatura adyacente, aferrando su corazón. El objetivo sufre @Damage[6d6[mental]]{6d6 daño mental} con una salvación @Check[will|dc:24|basic]. Con un fallo crítico, la criatura queda también @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralizada} hasta el inicio del siguiente turno del wraith.

action->Robes of Welcome.name: Ropajes de bienvenida
action->Robes of Welcome.description:
Frecuencia una vez por asalto

Efecto El wraith envuelve sus ropajes alrededor de una criatura viva adyacente, exponiéndola al abrazo del vacío. Si una criatura está ya maldita por el abrazo del vacío de un wraith, este no puede imponérselo a otra criatura.

action->Void's Embrace.name: Abrazo del vacío
action->Void's Embrace.description:
Si la víctima tiene éxito en una tirada de salvación contra esta maldición estando bajo la luz solar, la maldición se acaba. Mientras sufres esta maldición, superas la resistencia del wraith que te maldijo

Tirada de Salvación @Check[will|dc:24]

Etapa 1 la víctima está @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Deslumbrada} ante cualquier luz (1 hora)

Etapa 2 la víctima obtiene sentido de la vida 30 pies (9 m) pero está @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Cegada} ante cualquier luz (1 hora)

Etapa 3 como la Etapa 2, pero la criatura también dispone de @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.TTCw5NusiSSkJU1x]{Curación del vacío} (1 hora)

Etapa 4 la víctima queda @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Inconsciente} y no puede despertar (1 día)

Etapa 5 la criatura muere, se convierte en un wraith y su cuerpo se convierte en cenizas.

Wrathspawn.name: Engendro de la ira
Wrathspawn.publicNotes:
Los engendros pecaminosos fueron creados por uno de los siete antiguos magos conocidos colectivamente como los señores de las runas, cada uno de los cuales representaba y personificaba uno de los siete pecados capitales. El primer engendro pecaminoso fue creado por el Señor de las Runas de la Ira, utilizando técnicas que desde entonces han influenciado las técnicas de modelado de carne. No pasó mucho tiempo sin que la técnica utilizada para crear engendros pecaminosos cayera en manos de los demás señores de las runas y, si bien cada uno intentó mejorar variantes de diseño propio, hoy en día el engendro pecaminoso de la ira sigue siendo el más numeroso y el más notorio.

Con tan solo un vago parecido a los humanoides de cuya carne fueron formados, los engendros pecaminosos suelen parecer horriblemente demacrados, provistos de brazos antinaturalmente largos y piernas digitígradas, cada una provista de un trío de dedos cortos y dotados de garras. Las venas se les marcan a través del cuerpo en patrones sanguíneos que recuerdan sospechosamente a unas runas retorcidas, y tienen la piel pálida y lampiña. Su cabeza es alargada, con tan solo hendiduras nasales, los ojos rojos y una mandíbula inferior inquietante que se divide en dos por la barbilla, revelando unos pedipalpos que acaban en diminutas manos de tres dedos que enmarcan una lengua larga y colgante.

Los engendros pecaminosos miden 6,5 pies (1,95 m) de altura y típicamente pesan lo mismo que un humano demacrado de su tamaño. Se comportan de una forma consistente con su pecado asociado y tienen características físicas que apuntan a dichas cualidades. Por ejemplo por las venas de los engendros de la avaricia parece correr el oro y los engendros de la envidia parecen aún más consumidos que el resto de su especie.
Wrathspawn.saveDetails: +1 por estatus a las salvaciones contra la magia, +4 por estatus a las salvaciones contra mental

action->Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet.name: Olfato del pecado (impreciso) 30 pies (9 m)
action->Sin Scent (Imprecise) 30 feet.description:
Un engendro pecaminoso puede oler a las criaturas que reflejan su pecado como por la habilidad olfato. El DJ es quien determina qué criaturas son apropiadamente pecaminosas.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Scent]

action->+4 Status to All Saves vs. Menta.name: +4 por estatus a las salvaciones contra mental

action->Sinful Bite.name: Mordisco pecaminoso
action->Sinful Bite.description:
Una criatura impactada por las mandíbulas de un engendro pecaminoso debe hacer una salvación de @Check[will|dc:18] al ser asaltada por pensamientos pecaminosos.

Éxito crítico La criatura no resulta afectada

Éxito La criatura queda @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Indispuesta 1}

Fallo La criatura queda @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Indispuesta 2}

Fallo crítico La criatura queda indispuesta 2, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Torpe 1}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drenada 1} y @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Debilitada 1} durante 1 minuto

Wyvern.name: Wyvern
Wyvern.publicNotes:
A wyvern is a venomous drake with a well-earned reputation for impatience and aggression. As much as 15 feet long and weighing up to 1,000 pounds, a wyvern's resilient body allows them to crash talons-first into large prey without serious risk to themself. A wyvern uses their momentum to stun their target before injecting it with searing venom or carrying it over the side of a nearby cliff. Because a wyvern lacks the strength to haul their prey all the way to their nest intact, they're far more likely to lift and drop their victim over a gully or canyon and let gravity do its work before they descend to pick apart the carcass.

Conversation is of little interest to a wyvern, as the creature typically speaks only to taunt their prey, issue territorial claims, or demand tribute. Even so, many wyverns enjoy grim humor and tales of violent acts, particularly if those acts were committed by the storyteller. A wyvern properly appeased with meat, entertainment, and treasure sometimes agrees to provide assistance ranging from giving directions to serving as a mount for a powerful humanoid. However, these arrangements rarely last more than a few weeks before the wyvern's pride, malice, or insolence inspires them to flee or even betray their allies. Only the truly cruel can cow a wyvern into servitude for an extended period, as most wyverns are so self-interested that they go out of their way to avoid helping others.

Ravenous, bestial, and driven by instinct, drakes are draconic monsters who bear a fraction of the terrifying might of the primal dragons they share evolutionary roots with. While they're weaker, slower, and less inclined toward reason than dragons, drakes are nonetheless a menace to creatures and settlements around them. Their propensity for forming raiding parties—small social groups fittingly called "rampages"—makes them all the more dangerous; a single rampage of river drakes can quickly lay waste to a waterside village, and roving rampages of desert drakes are a plague to caravan traders.

Drakes share a number of physical characteristics that unite them as one species despite their wide variety of habitats and abilities. For example, drakes lack forearms, leaving them with their formidable jaws and thickscaled tails to use in close combat. Most drakes would rather avoid this, however, preferring to use their magical breath to wreak havoc in wide swaths from comfortable distances while flying overhead. Finally, all drakes have small reservoirs of their ancestral draconic power that they can tap into to perform incredible feats of speed.

Different species of drakes rarely come into conflict. Part of this is their distinct habitats, but drakes are open to negotiating simple agreements between rampages. This courtesy does not extend to dragonets, which drakes happily take as prey. Solitary tamed drakes are also excluded from such agreements and considered free game if their tamer isn't strong enough to protect them.

Drake Eggs

While drake hides aren't any more valuable than those of similarly sized creatures, drake eggs are prized commodities. They are used as components in powerful spells as well as eaten by various cultures, but the most common use for drake eggs is hatching and rearing drakes to serve as mounts and guardians.

A typical drake lays a clutch of 2d4 eggs every 5 years. Eggs hatch within 3 to 6 weeks, during which time they must be kept in conditions appropriate to their natural environment, perhaps the most difficult aspect of drake husbandry. While it is generally easy for breeders to incubate the eggs of desert or jungle drakes (which require mildly warm temperatures to hatch) or river drakes (which must be submerged in running water), the eggs of flame and frost drakes require extreme temperatures in order to hatch, which can be difficult to replicate safely.

A drake egg is an object with Hardness 3, 5 HP, and no Broken Threshold. The coloration of drake eggs varies only slightly from one species to the next. A creature must succeed at a @Check[nature|dc:20] check, or a relevant DC 20 Lore check, to identify the drake species of a specific egg.

Once a drake hatches, they imprint on the first creature that they see. A creature imprinted on in this way can use Nature to Train and Command that drake. The market price of a drake egg varies depending on the type of drake and the exact legal situation. Because drakes are dangerous and intelligent creatures, many societies do not condone the trade of drake eggs and criminalize those who engage in it.

It takes 2 years for a drake hatchling to grow to full size. A well-trained drake can make a fearsome mount or guardian, but many careless would-be drake trainers are devoured by their charges.

action->Savage.name: Savage
action->Savage.description:
Trigger A creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} by the wyvern critically fails a skill check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape}

Effect The wyvern makes a stinger Strike against the triggering creature.

action->Powerful Dive.name: Powerful Dive
action->Powerful Dive.description: The wyvern Flies up to their fly Speed and must both move forward at least 20 feet and descend at least 10 feet. If they end the movement within melee reach of at least one enemy their size or smaller, they can make a claw Strike against that enemy. If the claw hits, as a free action, the wyvern can either automatically Grab the target or knock it @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

action->Punishing Momentum.name: Punishing Momentum
action->Punishing Momentum.description:
Requirements The wyvern @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} a creature this turn using Powerful Dive

Effect The wyvern can Fly at half Speed while holding the creature in their claws, carrying that creature along with them and dropping it at the end of their movement. Alternatively, the wyvern can Strike the creature with their stinger with a +2 circumstance bonus.

action->Wyvern Venom.name: Wyvern Venom
action->Wyvern Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:22]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[3d6[poison]] damage (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[4d6[poison]] damage (1 round)

Xoarian.name: Xoariano
Xoarian.languages: (no puede hablar ningún idioma), telepatía 100 pies (30 m)
Xoarian.publicNotes:
Los xoarianos, criaturas con cinco tentáculos, se infiltran en muchas sociedades, aunque no queda claro qué parte del ejercicio es a petición del Dominio de la Oscuridad y que parte es para su propia y perversa diversión. Conocidos por los eruditos de Golarion como jinetes de cadáver, se sabe poco de sus orígenes más allá de la sospecha de que proceden de un planeta distante llamado Xoar.

Cuando un xoariano se infiltra en una comunidad, su primera prioridad es adquirir un cuerpo anfitrión. Para ello, suelen preferir a quienes han fallecido recientemente, porque asesinar a un anfitrión vivo podría atraer una atención no deseada. Cuando la aberración se comprime en la cavidad cerebral de un anfitrión, es capaz de hacer mover el cuerpo como si fuera el suyo. También adquiere una compleja gama de sentidos de los que normalmente carece.

Cada nuevo cuerpo trae la oportunidad de nuevos gustos, sonidos, vistas e incluso dolores. Cuando se reúnen en grupo, los xoarianos trabajan para aumentar su estatus y degustar las experiencias negadas a las clases inferiores. Los que controlan un cuerpo tienen poco que temer más allá de ser descubiertos, e incluso eso solo hace que pausar sus juegos. El daño al anfitrión es tan solo otra sensación que experimentar, y es fácil encontrar cuerpos de repuesto.

El Dominio de la Oscuridad es un conglomerado de conquistadores del espacio profundo, con una fuerte presencia en Aucturno, el planeta más remoto del sistema solar de Golarion. El Dominio tiene puestos avanzados secretos por todo Golarion; la mayoría de sus miembros en el planeta son exploradores, que utilizan sus habilidades para robar cerebros e identidades, reuniendo información sin tener consideración alguna por los habitantes de los mundos en los que se infiltran.

spell->Invisibility (At Will, Self Only).name: Invisibilidad (a voluntad, solo a si mismo)

action->Tremorsense 60 feet.name: Sentido de la vibración 60 pies (18 m)

action->Telepathy 100 feet.name: Telepatía 100 pies (30 m)

action->Stolen Identity.name: Identidad robada
action->Stolen Identity.description: Mientras un xoariano utiliza Ladrón de cuerpos, obtiene la aptitud de entender y hablar todos los idiomas conocidos por el anfitrión, así como el conocimiento de las aptitudes corporales de este, su identidad, su papel en la sociedad y su personalidad. Sin embargo no obtiene los recuerdos específicos o el conocimiento del cuerpo del anfitrión.

action->Thoughtsense 60 feet.name: Sentido de los pensamientos 60 pies (18 m)
action->Thoughtsense 60 feet.description: El xoariano siente la esencia mental de una criatura como un sentido preciso en el rango indicado; no puede sentir con él a las criaturas descerebradas.

action->Body Thief.name: Ladrón de cuerpos
action->Body Thief.description: El xoariano se apretuja en la cabeza de una criatura que no lleva muerta más de un día, consumiendo y reemplazando el cerebro de la misma. Al inicio del siguiente turno del xoariano, el cuerpo revive con su cantidad máxima de Puntos de Golpe, controlado por el xoariano, que es consciente y puede sentir todo lo que podría sentir el cuerpo poseído. Cualquier efecto que acaba con la posesión mata al cuerpo anfitrión con los mismos efectos de Salir del cuerpo. El xoariano no puede usar ninguno de los conjuros de la criatura anfitrión con Ladrón de cuerpos pero puede usar sus propios conjuros innatos.

action->Exit Body.name: Salir del cuerpo
action->Exit Body.description:
Requisitos El xoariano está controlando un cuerpo con Ladrón de cuerpos

Efecto El xoariano surge del cuerpo de su anfitrión, que muere instantáneamente y ya no se puede utilizar como anfitrión para una aptitud de Ladrón de cuerpos. El xoariano se extiende hasta su tamaño completo en un espacio adyacente.

action->Ravage.name: Consumir
action->Ravage.description: El xoariano da dos Golpes de tentáculo contra una sola criatura @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralizada}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Neutralizada} o @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Inconsciente}. Si al objetivo le quedan 0 Puntos de Golpe después de Consumir, el xoariano puede utilizar una acción gratuita con el rasgo muerte para matarlo y ocuparlo con Ladrón de cuerpos.

Xulgath Leader.name: Xulgath Leader
Xulgath Leader.publicNotes:
Xulgath leaders are usually the strongest, most violent members of a community—although in some cases, particularly in larger groups, xulgath clutches are led by powerful demon cultists or other monsters who seek to use the xulgaths as servants or sacrifices.

Reptilian humanoids who live in the uppermost reaches of the Darklands, xulgaths (known as troglodytes to many surface-dwelling folk) often attack intruders in their territory on sight. They live in simple familial communities called clutches, battling rival groups and other aggressive Darklands inhabitants in order to survive. They occasionally raid surface settlements, usually at the behest of cruel, bloodthirsty leaders who are often themselves in the thrall of more powerful creatures like nagas or demons. A typical xulgath has dull gray, dark gray, or ashen scales, with a long tail and bony protrusions that run the length of their spine. A typical xulgath is 5 feet tall and weighs 150 pounds.

Although today the xulgaths are brutal and scattered, they were one of the first intelligent humanoids to rise in the primeval world, once ruling over a mighty empire that stretched throughout the Darklands. Today, all that remains of this era are ruins of massive stone ziggurats and crumbling cities found within some of the larger caverns. Some groups of xulgaths continue to live among these ruins, venerating their ancestors' accomplishments, while others consider these areas taboo and leave them to become infested with Darklands vermin. Sages don't agree on why the ancient xulgath civilization fell. Some suspect it was the result of losing several wars waged against serpentfolk, while others suggest that the corruptive influence of demon worship rotted their culture from within.

Certainly, many xulgath settlements continue to worship demons to this day, paying homage and offering live sacrifices to demons or other terrible creatures from the Outer Rifts. Occasionally, a xulgath mystic can call forth and bind a lesser demon to help serve the group, but one who delves too deep into occultism might summon a more powerful fiend that either tears the xulgaths to pieces or seizes control of the settlement.

action->Stench.description:

30 feet @Check[fortitude|dc:19]

action->Weakening Strike.name: Weakening Strike
action->Weakening Strike.description: A creature hit by a xulgath leader's jaws or claw Strike is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} on a critical hit) for 1 round.

Xulgath Skulker.name: Xulgath Skulker
Xulgath Skulker.publicNotes:
Xulgath warrens are patrolled—some might say "haunted"—by the community's skulkers. These xulgaths specialize in stealth, striking swiftly from the shadows and otherwise ambushing foes.

Reptilian humanoids who live in the uppermost reaches of the Darklands, xulgaths (known as troglodytes to many surface-dwelling folk) often attack intruders in their territory on sight. They live in simple familial communities called clutches, battling rival groups and other aggressive Darklands inhabitants in order to survive. They occasionally raid surface settlements, usually at the behest of cruel, bloodthirsty leaders who are often themselves in the thrall of more powerful creatures like nagas or demons. A typical xulgath has dull gray, dark gray, or ashen scales, with a long tail and bony protrusions that run the length of their spine. A typical xulgath is 5 feet tall and weighs 150 pounds.

Although today the xulgaths are brutal and scattered, they were one of the first intelligent humanoids to rise in the primeval world, once ruling over a mighty empire that stretched throughout the Darklands. Today, all that remains of this era are ruins of massive stone ziggurats and crumbling cities found within some of the larger caverns. Some groups of xulgaths continue to live among these ruins, venerating their ancestors' accomplishments, while others consider these areas taboo and leave them to become infested with Darklands vermin. Sages don't agree on why the ancient xulgath civilization fell. Some suspect it was the result of losing several wars waged against serpentfolk, while others suggest that the corruptive influence of demon worship rotted their culture from within.

Certainly, many xulgath settlements continue to worship demons to this day, paying homage and offering live sacrifices to demons or other terrible creatures from the Outer Rifts. Occasionally, a xulgath mystic can call forth and bind a lesser demon to help serve the group, but one who delves too deep into occultism might summon a more powerful fiend that either tears the xulgaths to pieces or seizes control of the settlement.

action->Hidden Movement.name: Hidden Movement
action->Hidden Movement.description: If a xulgath skulker starts their turn @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VRSef5y1LmL2Hkjf]{Undetected} by a creature or merely @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} from it, that creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} against the skulker's attacks until the end of the skulker's turn.

action->Mask Stench.name: Mask Stench
action->Mask Stench.description: The stalker masks their stench with curated herbs, suppressing their stench aura. The skulker can resume their stench aura as a free action.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: A xulgath skulker deals an additional 1d6 precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

Xulgath Warrior.name: Xulgath Warrior
Xulgath Warrior.publicNotes:
Xulgath warriors strike with fury and eager cruelty, always ready for the next fight. The taking of prizes from battle—including weapons and items stolen from defeated foes along with grislier trophies harvested from fallen victims' flesh—is a popular pursuit among these vicious reptiles, and those whose armor and scales are most adorned are awarded the greatest respect (and perhaps fear) from their kin.

Reptilian humanoids who live in the uppermost reaches of the Darklands, xulgaths (known as troglodytes to many surface-dwelling folk) often attack intruders in their territory on sight. They live in simple familial communities called clutches, battling rival groups and other aggressive Darklands inhabitants in order to survive. They occasionally raid surface settlements, usually at the behest of cruel, bloodthirsty leaders who are often themselves in the thrall of more powerful creatures like nagas or demons. A typical xulgath has dull gray, dark gray, or ashen scales, with a long tail and bony protrusions that run the length of their spine. A typical xulgath is 5 feet tall and weighs 150 pounds.

Although today the xulgaths are brutal and scattered, they were one of the first intelligent humanoids to rise in the primeval world, once ruling over a mighty empire that stretched throughout the Darklands. Today, all that remains of this era are ruins of massive stone ziggurats and crumbling cities found within some of the larger caverns. Some groups of xulgaths continue to live among these ruins, venerating their ancestors' accomplishments, while others consider these areas taboo and leave them to become infested with Darklands vermin. Sages don't agree on why the ancient xulgath civilization fell. Some suspect it was the result of losing several wars waged against serpentfolk, while others suggest that the corruptive influence of demon worship rotted their culture from within.

Certainly, many xulgath settlements continue to worship demons to this day, paying homage and offering live sacrifices to demons or other terrible creatures from the Outer Rifts. Occasionally, a xulgath mystic can call forth and bind a lesser demon to help serve the group, but one who delves too deep into occultism might summon a more powerful fiend that either tears the xulgaths to pieces or seizes control of the settlement.

Yamaraj.name: Yamaraj
Yamaraj.publicNotes:
The greatest judges among the psychopomps are yamarajes, whose wisdom is legendary and whose edicts are unappealable except to ushers or Pharasma herself. A yamaraj resembles an immense dragon with dark, feathery scales and an emotionless, dispassionate gaze behind a feathered mask. When not serving as the senior magistrates, lords, and generals of the Boneyard, yamarajes pursue highly individualistic hobbies, such as gardening or literature.

Psychopomps are guardians and shepherds of the dead in the Boneyard, the vast plane of graves where mortal souls are judged and sent on to their eternal rewards or damnations. Psychopomps ensure that the dead come to terms with their transition from mortality and are properly sorted into the appropriate afterlife. They also protect souls from being preyed upon by supernatural predators. Nearly all psychopomps wear masks, especially when they're likely to be interacting with mortals, although the types of masks they wear are as varied as the psychopomps themselves. The courts of the Boneyard preside in Requian, a somber yet melodic language spoken slowly with various tonal shifts.

Many psychopomps are intimately involved with the Boneyard's massive bureaucracy. Few pursue mercy, justice, or personal gain; their duties to Pharasma and her Boneyard are supreme. Nevertheless, individual psychopomps interpret their duties in different ways, which might put them in conflict with mortals or even with each other.
Yamaraj.saveDetails: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->Lightning Drinker.name: Lightning Drinker
action->Lightning Drinker.description:
Whenever a yamaraj would take electricity damage if not for its immunity, its fast healing increases to 40 on its next turn.

During that turn, if it uses Beetle Breath, the beetles deal @Damage[2d12[electricity]]{2d12 additional electricity damage}.

action->Beetle Breath.name: Beetle Breath
action->Beetle Breath.description:
The yamaraj breathes a blast of beetles in a @Template[cone|distance:50] that deals @Damage[14d8[slashing],4d8[persistent,slashing]]{14d8 slashing damage and 4d8 persistent slashing damage} to creatures in the area with a @Check[reflex|dc:42|traits:damaging-effect] save.

It can't use Beetle Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Beetle Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes half damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}.

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 3}.

action->Final Judgment.name: Final Judgment
action->Final Judgment.description: A yamaraj's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.AuIiqc7jjiy1GZ75]{Manifestation} spells are used only to pronounce judgment, typically either to restore a dead or destroyed creature to life, bind a creature to the Boneyard, or banish a creature from the Boneyard.

action->Shepherd's Touch.name: Shepherd's Touch
action->Shepherd's Touch.description: A yamaraj's Strikes affect incorporeal creatures with the effects of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.JQdwHECogcTzdd8R]{Ghost Touch} property rune and deal @Damage[3d6[void]] damage to living creatures and @Damage[3d6[vitality]] damage to undead.

action->Yamaraj Venom.name: Yamaraj Venom
action->Yamaraj Venom.description:
While a creature is clumsy from this poison, it is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed} with the same value;

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:42]

Maximum Duration 10 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[3d8[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[5d8[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[7d8[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 3} (1 round)

Yeti.name: Yeti
Yeti.publicNotes:
Nearly a myth, a yeti is rarely seen—and even when it is, it is often too late. Yetis dwell amid the highest, most remote peaks of the world, coming down from their snowy mountain holds to raid, steal livestock, and sometimes feed their insatiable urges for slaughter and destruction. Those folks who live at the foot of a yeti-ruled mountain warn of the "abominable snowmen": monstrous, furcovered humanoids who leave strange and bloody tracks in the snow.

In actuality, most yetis protect the world rather than hunt its other denizens, guarding eldritch portals that link the mortal Universe and other, much stranger dimensions of reality. From within these snow-covered arches and ancient stone doorways, aliens, living nightmares, fiends, and worse can emerge into the world. Yetis who guard these portals sometimes succumb to the horrors within, taking on the bloodthirsty urges and horrific behaviors of the very monsters they strive to guard against. Driven out of their clans and forced to wander alone, they give rise to the myth of the abominable snowman. These exiled yetis often fully embrace the corrupting elements that caused their exile in the first place, growing more powerful and more deadly.
Yeti.saveDetails: +4 status to all saves vs. fear and dreams

action->Snowblind.name: Snowblind
action->Snowblind.description: When @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.XMcnh4cSI32tljXa]{Hiding}, the yeti is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} by any snowfall, even if it's not thick enough to make other creatures concealed.

action->Nightmare Guardian.name: Nightmare Guardian
action->Nightmare Guardian.description: Yetis gain a +4 status bonus to saves against fear and against spells and abilities that affect dreams. A yeti that falls prey to a supernatural nightmare loses this ability and becomes permanently enraged, gaining a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls and a -1 status penalty to AC.

action->Vanish.name: Vanish
action->Vanish.description:
Trigger The yeti is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VRSef5y1LmL2Hkjf]{Undetected} while not in combat, and a creature would observe it.

Effect The yeti Strides or Climbs up to half its Speed to a location where it can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.XMcnh4cSI32tljXa]{Hide}, then Hides. If its new Stealth check result meets or exceeds the triggering creature's Perception DC, the yeti remains hidden.

action->Arctic Passage.name: Arctic Passage
action->Arctic Passage.description: The yeti ignores difficult terrain caused by ice or snow.

action->Grizzly Arrival.name: Grizzly Arrival
action->Grizzly Arrival.description:
Trigger The yeti hits a creature in the first round of combat and the yeti was @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} from that creature at the start of combat.

Effect Each enemy within @Template[emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} that witnesses the attack (including the target of the attack) must attempt a @Check[will|dc:23] save. On a failure, the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2}; on a critical failure, it's @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 4}.
